metapy_toolbox package#

Submodules#

metapy_toolbox.benchmark module#

Benchmark functions for optimization.

ackley(x)#

The Ackley function in its two-dimensional form, it is characterized by a nearly flat outer region, and a large hole at the centre.

Parameters:

x (list) – Design variables

Return type:

float

Returns:

Objective function value

active_learning_example(x)#

Active learning function.

Parameters:

x (list) – Design variables

Return type:

float

Returns:

Objective function value

dixon_price(x)#

The dixon-price function is unimodal, and the global minimum lies in a narrow, parabolic valley.

Parameters:

x (list) – Design variables

Return type:

float

Returns:

Objective function value

easom(x)#

The Easom function has several local minima. It is unimodal, and the global minimum has a small area relative to the search space.

Parameters:

x (list) – Design variables

Return type:

float

Returns:

Objective function value

goldstein_price(x)#

The Goldstein-Price function has several local minima. Dimensions: 2

Parameters:

x (list) – Design variables

Return type:

float

Returns:

Objective function value

griewank(x)#

The Griewank function has many widespread local minima, which are regularly distributed.

Parameters:

x (list) – Design variables

Return type:

float

Returns:

Objective function value

michalewicz(x)#

The Michalewicz function has d! local minima, and it is multimodal. The parameter m defines the steepness of they valleys and ridges. A larger m leads to a more difficult search.

Parameters:

x (list) – Design variables

Return type:

float

Returns:

Objective function value

powell(x)#

The Powell function.

Parameters:

x (list) – Design variables

Return type:

float

Returns:

Objective function value

rastrigin(x)#

The Rastrigin function has several local minima. It is highly multimodal, but locations of the minima are regularly distributed.

Parameters:

x (list) – Design variables

Return type:

float

Returns:

Objective function value

rosenbrock(x)#

The Rosenbrock function is unimodal, and the global minimum lies in a narrow, parabolic valley.

Parameters:

x (list) – Design variables

Return type:

float

Returns:

Objective function value

sphere(x)#

The Sphere function has d local minima except for the global one. It is continuous, convex and unimodal.

Parameters:

x (list) – Design variables

Return type:

float

Returns:

Objective function value

zakharov(x)#

The Zakharov function has no local minima except the global one.

Parameters:

x (list) – Design variables

Return type:

float

Returns:

Objective function value

metapy_toolbox.ego module#

Efficient Global Optimization (EGO) related functions.

ego_01(obj, n_gen, params, initial_population, x_lower, x_upper, args=None, robustness=False)#

Efficient Global Optimization (EGO) algorithm.

Parameters:

  • obj (Callable) – The objective function: obj(x, args) -> float or obj(x) -> float, where x is a list with shape dim and args is a tuple fixed parameters needed to completely specify the function

  • n_gen (int) – Number of generations or iterations

  • params (dict) – Parameters of Genetic Algorithm

  • initial_population (list) – Initial population

  • x_lower (list) – Lower limit of the design variables

  • x_upper (list) – Upper limit of the design variables

  • robustness (Union[bool, dict]) – If True, the objective function is evaluated in a robust way (default is False)

  • args (Optional[tuple]) – Extra arguments to pass to the objective function (optional)

Returns:

[0] = All evaluations dataframe, [1] = Best, average and worst values dataframe, [2] = Report about the optimization process

filter_improvements(df, objective_column='OF', iteration_column='ITER', minimize=True)#

Filters a dataframe in EGO algorithm and sort the values to keep only the improvements.

Parameters:

  • df (DataFrame) – Data with all evaluations

  • objective_column (str)

  • iteration_column (str)

  • minimize (bool)

Return type:

DataFrame

Returns:

Data with only the improvements

metapy_toolbox.funcs module#

Commonly used functions.

best_avg_worst(df, d)#

Check and save best, average and worst objective function values from dataframe

Parameters:

  • df (DataFrame) – Dataframe with all data

  • d (int) – problem dimension

Return type:

DataFrame

Returns:

Positions, Objective function values saved

check_interval_01(x, x_lower, x_upper)#

This function checks if a design variable is out of the limits established x_lower and x_upper and updates the variable if necessary.

Parameters:

  • x (list) – Design variables to be checked

  • x_lower (list) – Lower limit of the design variables

  • x_upper (list) – Upper limit of the design variables

Return type:

list

Returns:

Checked design variables

compare_and_save(df_current, df_temp)#

Compare current and temporary solutions and save the best one.

Parameters:

  • df_current (DataFrame) – Positions, Objective function values, Fitness values and Time consumption saved of the current solution

  • df_temp (DataFrame) – Positions, Objective function values, Fitness values and Time consumption saved of the temporary solution

Return type:

DataFrame

Returns:

Positions, Objective function values, Fitness values and Time consumption saved of the best solution

evaluation(obj, id, x, t, args=None)#

Objective function evaluation and save in dataframe

Parameters:

  • obj (Callable) – The objective function: obj(x, args) -> float or obj(x) -> float, where x is a list with shape dim and args is a tuple fixed parameters needed to completely specify the function

  • id (int) – identifier of the agent

  • x (list) – Design variables to be evaluated

  • neof_count – Count of objective function evaluations

  • t (int) – Current iteration number

  • args (Optional[tuple]) – Extra arguments to pass to the objective function (optional)

Return type:

DataFrame

Returns:

Positions, Objective function values, Fitness values and Time consumption saved

fit_value(of_i_value)#

Calculates the fitness value of the i-th agent based on its objective function value.

Parameters:

of_i_value (float) – Objective function value of the i-th agent in t time step

Return type:

float

Returns:

Fitness value of the i-th agent in t time step (always positive)

initial_population_01(n_population, n_dimensions, x_lower, x_upper, seed=None, use_lhs=True, scramble=True)#

Generates an initial population of continuous variables within the specified bounds. If use_lhs=True: uses Latin Hypercube Sampling (scipy.stats.qmc.LatinHypercube). If use_lhs=False: uses numpy uniform RNG.

Parameters:

  • n_population (int) – number of individuals in the population.

  • n_dimensions (int) – number of dimensions (variables) in the problem.

  • x_lower (list) – lower bounds per dimension (size n_dimensions).

  • x_upper (list) – upper bounds per dimension (size n_dimensions).

  • seed (int) – random seed for reproducibility. Default None.

  • use_lhs (bool) – True to use Latin Hypercube (default). False to use pure uniform sampling.

  • scramble (bool) – only for LHS — if True, enables scrambling (shuffling) in the LHS.

Returns:

generated population, format [n_population][n_dimensions].

Example

>>> import numpy as np
>>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
>>> x_lower = [0, -5]
>>> x_upper = [10, 5]
>>> n_population = 20
>>> n_dimensions = 2
>>> seed = 42
>>> pop2d = initial_population_01(n_population, n_dimensions, x_lower, x_upper, seed, use_lhs=True)
>>> pop2d = np.array(pop2d)
>>> plt.figure(figsize=(6, 5))
>>> plt.scatter(pop2d[:, 0], pop2d[:, 1], c='blue', s=50, label='Population')
>>> plt.title("Initial Population (2D)")
>>> plt.xlabel("X1")
>>> plt.ylabel("X2")
>>> plt.legend()
>>> plt.show()
initial_population_01_opposite(n_population, n_dimensions, x_lower, x_upper, seed=None, use_lhs=True, scramble=True)#

Generates an initial population and its opposite population of continuous variables. The opposite population is computed as: x_opposite = x_lower + x_upper - x.

Parameters:

  • n_population (int) – number of individuals in the population.

  • n_dimensions (int) – number of dimensions (variables) in the problem.

  • x_lower (list) – lower bounds per dimension (size n_dimensions).

  • x_upper (list) – upper bounds per dimension (size n_dimensions).

  • seed (int) – random seed for reproducibility. Default None.

  • use_lhs (bool) – True to use Latin Hypercube (default). False to use pure uniform sampling.

  • scramble (bool) – only for LHS — if True, enables scrambling (shuffling) in the LHS.

Returns:

tuple of two lists: (initial_population, opposite_population)

Example

>>> import numpy as np
>>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
>>> x_lower = [0, -5]
>>> x_upper = [10, 5]
>>> n_population = 20
>>> n_dimensions = 2
>>> seed = 42
>>> pop, pop_opp = initial_population_01_opposite( n_population, n_dimensions, x_lower, x_upper, seed, use_lhs=True)
>>> pop = np.array(pop)
>>> pop_opp = np.array(pop_opp)
>>> plt.figure(figsize=(6, 5))
>>> plt.scatter(pop[:, 0], pop[:, 1], c='blue', s=50, label='Population')
>>> plt.scatter(pop_opp[:, 0], pop_opp[:, 1], c='red', marker='x', s=60, label='Opposite')
>>> plt.title("Initial vs Opposite Population (2D)")
>>> plt.xlabel("X1")
>>> plt.ylabel("X2")
>>> plt.legend()
>>> plt.show()
initial_population_01_quasi_opposite(n_population, n_dimensions, x_lower, x_upper, seed=None, use_lhs=True, scramble=True)#

Generates an initial population and its quasi-opposite population of continuous variables. The quasi-opposite population perturbs around the midpoint between bounds based on the opposite population.

Parameters:

  • n_population (int) – number of individuals in the population.

  • n_dimensions (int) – number of dimensions (variables) in the problem.

  • x_lower (list) – lower bounds per dimension (size n_dimensions).

  • x_upper (list) – upper bounds per dimension (size n_dimensions).

  • seed (int) – random seed for reproducibility. Default None.

  • use_lhs (bool) – True to use Latin Hypercube (default). False to use pure uniform sampling.

  • scramble (bool) – only for LHS — if True, enables scrambling (shuffling) in the LHS.

Returns:

tuple of two lists: (initial_population, quasi_opposite_population)

Example

>>> import numpy as np
>>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
>>> x_lower = [0, -5]
>>> x_upper = [10, 5]
>>> n_population = 20
>>> n_dimensions = 2
>>> seed = 42
>>> pop, pop_quasi = initial_population_01_quasi_opposite(n_population, n_dimensions, x_lower, x_upper, seed, use_lhs=True)
>>> pop = np.array(pop)
>>> pop_quasi = np.array(pop_quasi)
>>> plt.figure(figsize=(6, 5))
>>> plt.scatter(pop[:, 0], pop[:, 1], c='blue', s=50, label='Population')
>>> plt.scatter(pop_quasi[:, 0], pop_quasi[:, 1], c='orange', marker='x', s=60, label='Quasi-Opposite')
>>> plt.title("Initial vs Quasi-Opposite Population (2D)")
>>> plt.xlabel("X1")
>>> plt.ylabel("X2")
>>> plt.legend()
>>> plt.show()
mutation_01_random_walk(parent_0, pdf, cov, x_lower, x_upper)#

This function performs the random walk mutation operator. Three new points are generated from the two parent points (offspring).

Parameters:

  • parent_0 (list) – First parent

  • pdf (str) – Probability density function. Options: ‘gaussian’, ‘uniform’ or ‘gumbel’

  • cov (float) – Coefficient of variation

  • x_lower (list) – Lower limit of the design variables

  • x_upper (list) – Upper limit of the design variables

Return type:

tuple[list, str]

Returns:

[0] = First offspring position, [1] = Report about the linear crossover process

query_x_of_fit_from_data(df, i, d)#

Query position, objective function value and fitness value of the i-th agent from dataframe

Parameters:

  • df (DataFrame) – All data in time step t

  • i (int) – Current agent in t time step

  • d (int) – Number of dimensions

Return type:

tuple[list, float, float]

Returns:

[0] = Position of the i-th agent in t time step, [1] = Objective function value of the i-th agent in t time step, [2] = Fitness value of the i-th agent in t time step

metapy_toolbox.genetic_algorithm module#

Genetic Algorithm related functions.

arithmetic_crossover(parent_0, parent_1, n_dimensions, x_upper, x_lower)#

This function performs the arithmetic crossover operator. Two new points are generated from the two parent points (offspring).

Parameters:

  • parent_0 (list) – Current design variables of the first parent.

  • parent_1 (list) – Current design variables of the second parent.

  • n_dimensions (int) – Problem dimension.

  • x_lower (list) – Lower limit of the design variables.

  • x_upper (list) – Upper limit of the design variables.

Return type:

tuple[list, list, str]

Returns:

[0] = First offspring position, [1] = Second offspring position, [2] = Report about the arithmetic crossover process

binomial_crossover(parent_0, parent_1, p_c, n_dimensions, x_upper, x_lower)#

This function performs the binomial crossover operator. Two new points are generated from the two parent points (offspring).

Parameters:

  • parent_0 (list) – Current design variables of the first parent.

  • parent_1 (list) – Current design variables of the second parent.

  • p_c (float) – Crossover probability rate (0–1).

  • n_dimensions (int) – Problem dimension.

  • x_lower (list) – Lower limit of the design variables.

  • x_upper (list) – Upper limit of the design variables.

Return type:

tuple[list, list, str]

Returns:

[0] = First offspring position, [1] = Second offspring position, [2] = Report about the binomial crossover process

blxalpha_crossover(parent_0, parent_1, x_lower, x_upper)#

This function performs the BLX-alpha crossover operator. Two new points are generated from the two parent points (offspring).

Parameters:

  • parent_0 (list) – First parent

  • parent_1 (list) – Second parent

  • x_lower (list) – Lower limit of the design variables

  • x_upper (list) – Upper limit of the design variables

Return type:

tuple[list, list, str]

Returns:

[0] = First offspring position, [1] = Second offspring position, [2] = Report about the linear crossover process

genetic_algorithm_01(obj, n_gen, params, initial_population, x_lower, x_upper, args=None, robustness=False)#

Genetic algorithm 01. Supports: roulette wheel selection, linear crossover and random walk mutation.

Parameters:

  • obj (Callable) – The objective function: obj(x, args) -> float or obj(x) -> float, where x is a list with shape dim and args is a tuple fixed parameters needed to completely specify the function

  • n_gen (int) – Number of generations or iterations

  • params (dict) – Parameters of Genetic Algorithm

  • initial_population (list) – Initial population

  • x_lower (list) – Lower limit of the design variables

  • x_upper (list) – Upper limit of the design variables

  • robustness (Union[bool, dict]) – If True, the objective function is evaluated in a robust way (default is False)

  • args (Optional[tuple]) – Extra arguments to pass to the objective function (optional)

Return type:

tuple[DataFrame, DataFrame, str]

Returns:

[0] = All evaluations dataframe, [1] = Best, average and worst values dataframe, [2] = Report about the optimization process

heuristic_crossover(parent_0, parent_1, n_dimensions, x_upper, x_lower)#

This function performs the heuristic crossover operator. Two new points are generated from the two parent points (offspring).

Parameters:

  • parent_0 (list) – Current design variables of the first parent.

  • parent_1 (list) – Current design variables of the second parent.

  • n_dimensions (int) – Problem dimension.

  • x_lower (list) – Lower limit of the design variables.

  • x_upper (list) – Upper limit of the design variables.

Return type:

tuple[list, list, str]

Returns:

[0] = First offspring position, [1] = Second offspring position, [2] = Report about the linear crossover process

laplace_crossover(parent_0, parent_1, mu, sigma, n_dimensions, x_upper, x_lower)#

This function performs the Laplace crossover operator. Two new points are generated from the two parent points (offspring).

Parameters:

  • parent_0 (list) – Current design variables of the first parent.

  • parent_1 (list) – Current design variables of the second parent.

  • mu (float) – Location parameter.

  • sigma (float) – Scale parameter.

  • n_dimensions (int) – Problem dimension.

  • x_lower (list) – Lower limit of the design variables.

  • x_upper (list) – Upper limit of the design variables.

Return type:

tuple[list, list, str]

Returns:

[0] = First offspring position, [1] = Second offspring position, [2] = Report about the Laplace crossover process

linear_crossover(parent_0, parent_1, x_lower, x_upper)#

This function performs the linear crossover operator. Three new points are generated from the two parent points (offspring).

Parameters:

  • parent_0 (list) – First parent

  • parent_1 (list) – Second parent

  • x_lower (list) – Lower limit of the design variables

  • x_upper (list) – Upper limit of the design variables

Return type:

tuple[list, list, list, str]

Returns:

[0] = First offspring position, [1] = Second offspring position, [2] = Third offspring position, [3] = Report about the linear crossover process

mp_crossover(chromosome_a, chromosome_b, seed, of_function, none_variable)#

Multi-point ordered crossover.

Parameters:

  • chromosome_a (ndarray) – Current design variables of the first parent.

  • chromosome_b (ndarray) – Current design variables of the second parent.

  • seed (int | None) – Seed for pseudo-random numbers generation, by default None.

  • of_function (callable) – Objective function. The Metapy user defined this function.

  • none_variable (any) – None variable. Default is None. User can use this variable in objective function.

Return type:

tuple[ndarray, ndarray]

Returns:

Tuple of chromosomes after crossover.

mp_mutation(chromosome, seed, of_chro, of_function, none_variable)#

Multi-point inversion mutation. A random mask encodes which elements will keep the original order or the reversed one.

Parameters:

  • chromosome (ndarray) – Current design variables of the individual.

  • seed (int | None) – Seed for pseudo-random numbers generation, by default None.

  • of_chro (float) – Objective function value of the chromosome before mutation.

  • of_function (callable) – Objective function. The Metapy user defined this function.

  • none_variable (any) – None variable. Default is None. User can use this variable in objective function.

Return type:

tuple[ndarray, float, float, int]

Returns:

Tuple of chromosome after mutation, objective function value after mutation, fitness value after mutation, number of evaluations of the objective function.

multi_point_crossover(of_function, parent_0, parent_1, n_dimensions, x_upper, x_lower, none_variable=None)#

This function performs the multi point crossover operator. Two new points are generated from the two parent points (offspring).

Parameters:

  • of_function (Callable) – Objective function. The Metapy user defined this function.

  • parent_0 (List[float]) – Current design variables of the first parent.

  • parent_1 (List[float]) – Current design variables of the second parent.

  • n_dimensions (int) – Problem dimension.

  • x_lower (List[float]) – Lower limit of the design variables.

  • x_upper (List[float]) – Upper limit of the design variables.

  • none_variable (Union[None, List[float], float, Dict[str, float], str]) – None variable. Default is None. User can use this variable in objective function.

Return type:

Tuple[List[float], float, float, int, str]

Returns:

A tuple containing: - x_i_new (List): Update variables of the i agent. - of_i_new (Float): Update objective function value of the i agent. - fit_i_new (Float): Update fitness value of the i agent. - neof (Integer): Number of evaluations of the objective function. - report (String): Report about the crossover process.

roulette_wheel_selection(fit_pop, i_pop)#

This function selects a position from the population using the roulette wheel selection method.

Parameters:

  • fit_pop (list) – Population fitness values

  • i_pop (int) – current agent in t time step

Return type:

tuple[int, str]

Returns:

[0] = selected agent id, [1] = Report about the roulette wheel selection process.

simulated_binary_crossover(parent_0, parent_1, eta_c, n_dimensions, x_upper, x_lower)#

This function performs the simulated binary crossover operator. Two new points are generated from the two parent points (offspring).

Parameters:

  • parent_0 (list) – Current design variables of the first parent.

  • parent_1 (list) – Current design variables of the second parent.

  • eta_c (float) – Distribution index.

  • n_dimensions (int) – Problem dimension.

  • x_lower (list) – Lower limit of the design variables.

  • x_upper (list) – Upper limit of the design variables.

Return type:

tuple[list, list, str]

Returns:

[0] = First offspring position, [1] = Second offspring position, [2] = Report about the simulated binary crossover process

single_point_crossover(of_function, parent_0, parent_1, n_dimensions, x_upper, x_lower, none_variable=None)#

This function performs the single point crossover operator. Two new points are generated from the two parent points (offspring).

Parameters:

  • of_function (Callable) – Objective function. The Metapy user defined this function.

  • parent_0 (List[float]) – Current design variables of the first parent.

  • parent_1 (List[float]) – Current design variables of the second parent.

  • n_dimensions (int) – Problem dimension.

  • x_lower (List[float]) – Lower limit of the design variables.

  • x_upper (List[float]) – Upper limit of the design variables.

  • none_variable (Union[None, List[float], float, Dict[str, float], str]) – None variable. Default is None. User can use this variable in objective function.

Return type:

Tuple[List[float], float, float, int, str]

Returns:

A tuple containing: - x_i_new (List): Update variables of the i agent. - of_i_new (Float): Update objective function value of the i agent. - fit_i_new (Float): Update fitness value of the i agent. - neof (Integer): Number of evaluations of the objective function. - report (String): Report about the crossover process.

tournament_selection(fit, i, n_pop, runs)#

This function selects a position from the population using the tournament selection method.

Parameters:

  • fit (ndarray) – Population fitness values

  • i (int) – current agent in t time step

  • n_pop (int) – Population size

  • runs (int) – Number of tournaments

Return type:

int

Returns:

selected agent id

uniform_crossover(parent_0, parent_1, n_dimensions, x_upper, x_lower)#

This function performs the uniform crossover operator. Two new points are generated from the two parent points (offspring).

Parameters:

  • parent_0 (list) – Current design variables of the first parent.

  • parent_1 (list) – Current design variables of the second parent.

  • n_dimensions (int) – Problem dimension.

  • x_lower (list) – Lower limit of the design variables.

  • x_upper (list) – Upper limit of the design variables.

Return type:

tuple[list, list, str]

Returns:

[0] = First offspring position, [1] = Second offspring position, [2] = Report about the uniform crossover process
